segments.text: General O.D.
Butler.
Today is August 8th, 1980.
This is the third interview with General Butler.
This is Terry Anderson and this is a test.
This is the third interview with General O.D.
Butler.
Today is August 8th, 1980.
This is Terry Anderson.
During the last two interviews, we've discussed your early years, your education here at Texas A&M, and your active and some of your reserve duty in the Army.
I'd like to turn now to the commands in the reserve that you've had and also to the attitudes and opinions on leadership and other aspects of military life.
In 1955, you were the commander of the 343 Field Artillery Battalion.
Why were you chosen?
Well, I can't say exactly why.
I was a fairly young major.
Came back and immediately resumed activities in the Army Reserve in the early days, 1946, 47, even before the policy was established that there would be

inactive duty pay for reserves of course our reserve activities prior to world war ii were voluntary and unpaid right so i was in activities there i suppose i had been one of the most consistent in participation over a long period of time had some seniority that was your first command wasn't it
Well, it was the first battalion.
Battalion command, right.
Battery commander.
Right, but I mean that was your first battalion-sized command.
Yes, it was.
What were your functions and duties?
Well, a battalion of field artillery has a combat mission to support the infantry, our tank battalions.
We attempted to carry that out.
The battalion has three firing batteries equipped with pouchers, a headquarters battery, and a service battery.
So there were five battery-sized units.
Commander
The Army said that the commander is responsible for everything his unit does or fails to do, so that's a summary of what you do as a commander.
Okay, what did you do with the battalion?
All right, the battalion was responsible for training for all of the
table of organization, authorized positions, and responsible for maintaining the functionality of the substantial equipment that one has in a unit.
So we would make out, of course, the objectives of training for a year.

conduct the training and try to bring all of the unit members up to a maximum level of training prior to our two weeks of active duty for training, where we would go to an Army post and perform functions as any active Army unit would by those periods.
How many men did you have, full strength?
Oh, full strength.
Of a battalion there would be something over 500 men.
500 men and what type of equipment did you have?
We had 105 millimeter howitzers.
Towed.
How many 105's?
Well actually for training we had two per firing battery.
At that time we did not have full strength units.
That's all we needed for training and when we would go to active duty we could
draw additional houses from the units on the post where we were assigned if we needed them in addition to our own houses.
Where was your headquarters?
Headquarters was right here at College Station.
In 1955, as I recall, we had just prepared the old Marion Pugh Lumber Company warehouse
the government leased and we used that for a headquarters building.
It was later converted to apartments after the U.S. Army Reserve Center was built on Carson Street between Color Station Bryan and the city limits of Bryan.
Now in 1959 you changed command.
You became the CEO of the 4th Howitzer Battalion.
Why'd you change duty?
We didn't change duty.
That was just a redesignation of the same organization.
Were you still a major at that time?
I don't know.
It seemed to me like I'd been promoted in the meanwhile.
Actually, I commanded that battalion prior to 1951.
I was a battalion commander when I went to do graduate work at Michigan State University in 1951.
And I was a major at that time, but I got promoted to lieutenant colonel somewhere along in the middle 50's.
That's on the record there somewhere.
I know I was kind of resentful.
I commanded that battalion for three years as a major.
And the
Artillery, I mean the active army advisor assigned to us never recommended me for a promotion because he said I was too young to be promoted.
I was a little resentful of that at the time, but it later proved to be an advantage.
Well, according to your biographical sketch, you first became the commander in 1955.
Well, 897th.
Headquarters, 75th.
You see in clear up here, 352nd Armored Field Artillery Battalion.
So that's when I first became a battalion commander.
1 July, 49.
Okay.
Now, how did you change from artillery to engineering?
Okay, that was because the 90th
Infantry Division, U.S. Army Reserve, was deactivated.
It was during the McNamara era when he was the Secretary of Defense.
They changed policies and decided to emphasize combat units
in the National Guard and combat support units in the Army Reserve.
So the 90th Infantry Division was deactivated and all of us in 90th Infantry Division units that wanted to be were reassigned to other Army Reserve units to vacancies if they existed.
If not, we were assigned as over strength
So I was first assigned as an over-strength officer to the 420th engineer brigade.
What was your opinion of McNamara?
Well, I thought he had a lot of genius, surrounded himself with brilliant people, sort of think tank group people.
Though I thought at the time, and still believe that this probably was a mistake, that it weakened the Tova Reserve structure to concentrate, to make the changes that were made at that time.
Did the Cold War and the Soviet-American tensions of the 1950s have anything to do with our effect in any way, the reserves?
Well, sure.
One Cold War effect that is advantageous to reserves is an actual draft or threat of a draft that would cause young people to choose between the possibility or probability of doing their service
in the active forces are satisfying their requirement by membership in the reserves.
To me, that's the main way that the reserves gain adequate support, recruiting, get the kind of talent required to be effective.
Then during the 1950s, when you were in command, you did not have problems with
reserve or getting volunteers?
Well at that particular time with the Korean War and the draft as I recall we had a fairly substantial waiting list in all of our organizations so we could be very selective.
And how would you select a potential officer or a potential enlisted man?
Well actually the officers
were selected by an entirely different method.
Of course, at that time, we had access to a number of officers, and we looked at their qualifications for the vacancy we had, their military occupational specialty and their previous record.
And of course, you can check those with the officer's efficiency report, which were required.
Those reports were required and still are.
wasn't too difficult to select the highest qualified officers.
Now for enlisted men, of course, we selected them based upon their scores on their tests for recruitment, upon their
desires to train.
If they wanted to do certain specialties, let's say communications for which we had some vacancies and were willing to go to school to take those, we'd naturally get preference for that.
As I recall at that time too, we were fortunate in being able to utilize the ROTC cadets

it was very advantageous for the ROTC cadet to be in the Army reserves, because if they had three years of good service with the reserves prior to their being commissioned, they would automatically collect the longevity pay, which as I recall amounted to about $75 a month, and so they could start out higher.
Of course, this would be an advantage all the time they were associated with the Army.
And besides that,
Obviously, they had an orientation toward the military, or they wouldn't have been in Texas A&M.
They wouldn't have taken advance to ROTC, so they were the very best soldiers we could get.
Now, you became the commander of the 420th in 1971.
Do you remember what your aims were?
Aims?
I wanted to have the best engineer brigade in the Army Reserves and one of the very best Army Reserve military organizations.
Okay, how did you go about that?

Well, in the first place, a brigade headquarters like this could be very, very well supported around Texas A&M University because there are so many highly qualified and motivated reservists in this area.
I was not a qualified engineer, so naturally I leaned heavily on selection of highly qualified engineers and gave them the maximum authority and responsibility I could.
I leaned on their expertise to do the job.
The main thing I would do for the different sections is to set their goals and help to select steps
objectives and steps for achievement of these goals and objectives, whatever they might be.
We had high demands on performance, and people that didn't come up to these standards, we'd try to find a better one to do that.
What type of operations did you go on?
Well, this was a wonderful experience.
An engineer
brigade like this, this one had two construction battalions and two combat battalions.
And we could have home station projects for construction that would allow us to exercise all of the skills and utilize the equipment, as long as we worked for public service type units.
For instance, we could construct things for Texas A&M University
Did you?
Oh, yes, we did some.
For example?
We had a utility detachment right here at the headquarters.
A utility detachment does the same sort of things on an Army post as the Office of Physical Plants does at Texas A&M.
We affiliated the utility detachment with the carpenters, plumbers, electricians, et cetera, at Texas A&M.
We built some things, for instance, out at the Farmers Training School.
quite a bit of activity there.
And over the years, we've also done civic projects for the city of Bryan.
We rehabilitated an old school house out on Highway 21, Dilley Shaw Tap Road, that's used for a mental health, mental retardation facility.
We had a number of projects like that.
Could you give me some specific examples of projects, for example, with Bryan and Texas A&M?
Yes, we did construction for the city of Bryan on Little League Park.
Did you really?
Yes.
Backstops, hauling dirt, leveling fields, whatever needed to be done.
All of those were training projects for...
Certain sections.
And you do these on weekends?
Sure.
That's a great idea.
We would have a continuing project.
We probably couldn't accomplish it in one weekend duty for training, but over a year we'd get quite a lot done.
Now that raises an interesting question.
You're doing work for the university.
You're doing work for the city, which means that they are not having bids from construction companies to do that.
Yes.
What did the businessmen in the community think of these projects?
Well, they...
policy of the Department of Defense is that the contractors in an area had to be supportive of these things.
Usually we'd work on projects that were so small that they weren't really of interest to contractors.
But as a part of our submission of such projects for approval by Fifth Army headquarters, and they in some cases might even have to forward projects to Department of Army for approval,
We were required to show substantial evidence that there was an objection of the local contractors to what we were gonna do.
That's a good question and it is an important thing but you know in some cases the same people that performed these functions on weekends were contractors themselves.
So they
Usually we're acquainted with contractors of different nature.
For instance, Len Stewart, who's now the commander of the engineer brigade, is one of the good construction contractors in this area.
Still is.
Stewart and Thurmond.
He built, for instance, a new baseball stadium over here that takes the name University S. Well, that's kind of a project that his contracting firm is interested in.
Of course, that's out of the question for an Army Reserve unit to take on
training project.
But we could build, for instance, the shelters and slabs for the Furman's Training School, which we did in some cases.
We could build the ponds around the animal science area.
It's a swine center.
Those are two of the...
So the projects then you did were not major projects, but they were projects like the Little League Fields.
That's very interesting.
Yes.
We didn't do everything around Little League Fields.
We would take on, for instance, the leveling, the grading, the survey.
Of course, we had a fine survey section.
I remember my survey section was the first one to lay out the polo field on the...
photo grounds out here, Texas A&M, and also our motor graders dump trucks did some work related to that.
We repainted and rehabilitated one of the homes used by some of the welfare agencies of the city of Bryan.
I see.
What about on your two weeks?
excursions.
Tell me about the type of operations you did there.
Okay depending upon whether it was a combat battalion or a construction battalion.
A construction battalion would work with the post engineer for instance if we went to Camp Willis near San Antonio, Texas or to let's say

Fort Hood which we did sometime we would work well in advance with the post engineer and be given projects where he would furnish the materials we would prepare the plans and do the actual construction and our requirements were that these projects would train all of the people in the various military occupational specialties that we had and would utilize fully our equipment
at the time we were on the two weeks active duty for training.
We went to Fort Sill, Oklahoma.
We went to Albuquerque, New Mexico.
Had an airlift up there one time, moved construction to construction companies up there by military airlift.
Now was that under your command or was that under General Hanover's command?
I know he was talking- Hanover was commanding when we did that particular
And you were his deputy at that time?
I was, yes.
And did you continue the airlifts under your command?
Well, we, I'm not sure whether we had an additional one.
We requested airlifts all the way to Germany.
We never got it.
Oh, did you really?
During our command, but since then, the brigade has been authorized, the Corps Engineer Section,
affiliated with Third Corps actually at Fort Hood, Texas.
And they went to Germany this past summer.
Part of their activities.
So we did seek overseas assignments.
We had some pretty exotic assignments, all right.
Our two utility detachments were at, were in Arkansas.
when the big Vietnam refugee group came in, Fort Chaffee, Arkansas.
So we actually performed, about a month before the arrival of these refugees, we performed exactly the same kind of duties that those utility detachments would on mobilization.
That is, we prepared housing, put in plumbing, reactivated some of the old facilities at Fort Chaffee.
Got involved in rehabilitation of the whole sewage disposal system up there.
Exactly the same sort of duties the soldiers would have been doing.
You prepared the camp then for the refugees.
That's right, sure did.
Did you?
We assisted them, of course.
Sure, there were others.
There was an active army engineer battalion down there too.
As a matter of fact, they used a lot of our equipment.
After we left, the equipment stayed there.
one of the battalions of the 101st Airborne Division was there using our equipment and working on certain aspects of the post to ready that for the Vietnam refugees.
Now that was under your command.
Did you visit Port Chaffee?
Of course.
I stayed there.
Our headquarters was there for two or three years.
So you stayed there during when the refugees were incoming?
Yes.
Can you tell me, that's a rather important historical event, can you tell me about that?
Well they... What were their conditions and what were the people like?
Well the refugees were crowded into army barracks there, but that was so much better than they'd been in that they were appreciated very much.
because we've had some demonstration by Cubans up there in the same facilities this year, and apparently some of those Cubans were not the most desirable kind of people.
But as far as I know, there was never any problem with any of the Vietnamese.
They were crowded.
They were uncomplaining about living in the old World War II type wooden barracks.
Of course, they had full medical support from the Army hospital there.
And of course, there were a number of births.
And gosh, I've forgotten.
There's somewhere between 5,000 and 10,000 of those refugees there.
During all the time they were there, they were fairly well restricted to barracks area.
This area was, of course, accessible to us during working hours as we worked on facilities, but off limits.
And of course, the Vietnamese were
carefully contained in these areas at the time.
They appeared to be healthy enough and seemed very happy to be over here.
How about schooling?
Was there an effort made to teach them English or anything like that?
I'm not sure about that.
I know that
The active army people there had programs going on with guns, I'm not aware of what it was.
How about food?
This is an oriental now, eating American food, is that right?
They were eating?
Yes, they were.
How'd they adjust to that?
They seemed to be very, very well.
There's such a variety of food.
taken care of on food in the army that there just wasn't any problem with that.
I'm sure that they adjusted the ration some, the increased supply of rice or that sort of thing to adjust as much as they could to the previous diet of the Vietnamese.
However, I think they took to American diets fairly well too.
Now you said they were happy to be here.
Did you say that because they seemed friendly and smiled a lot, they were a good disposition, or why?
Well, Orientals are somewhat inscrutable.
They don't smile a lot, apparently, but of course they, in this particular group of people, there were a lot of high-class professional people.
They seemed to have well-recognized leaders who interacted with the military personnel.
They seemed to be well-disciplined and that is that they were quite cooperative.
So those were characteristics I noted, not any
great expression of exuberance or happiness or demonstrativeness like we might expect of the same age people, Americans.
How about the relations between the Arkansas people and the Vietnamese?
Well there were actually no interactions at that time at all.
As I say, at that time the Vietnamese were brought in there by air to the near
nearby air base, they were brought into this compound and restricted to it.
Of course, early on they did start relocating these refugees to places that wanted them.
Houston or Dallas or wherever.
Those arrangements seemed to go quite well.
And of course, as we got into Fort Smith, Arkansas and around, it did stimulate business there.
For instance, the post engineer went into Fort Smith and bought every hammer he could find anywhere to outfit all the people that started rehabilitating the quarters around Fort Chaffee.
So there was a lot of local purchase of different things.
How did your men perform under your command at Fort Jaffe?
Outstanding.
Both of my utility detachments received very high ratings for what they did.
Now you see, they normally would have been living in these same barracks, or my whole organization might have been in there.
But during this time, we were living in tents.
We were not provided
quarters as good as the Vietnamese refugees were.
But our men very willingly worked long hours and were dedicated to doing the job.
Was it because their quarters weren't as good?
Did you think they were resentful?
No, not at all.
They knew it was a temporary thing with them of course.
They had lived in tents before.
Well-led, well-disciplined troops don't mind such things as that.
How many men were there on these two detachments?
The utility detachments have about 50 people in each detachment.
And how much time did you spend up there?
Well, each time the utility detachment was there, if I was the only one there, I would usually visit for one day or two days to look over all their projects.
